body:
[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/mettuaditya/graphlb.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/mettuaditya/graphlb)
# graphlb
graphlb is a crystal library which contains all the graph datastructures and algorithms in crystal-lang.

Please find the Documentation [here](https://mettuaditya.github.io/graphlb/)

# Installation

Clone repository manually:

```sh
$ git clone https://github.com/mettuaditya/graphlb && cd graphlb/
```
or  add this to your application's `shard.yml`:

```yaml
dependencies:
  crystalg:
    github: mettuaditya/graphlb
```

Then run `shards install`


# To Do

* Algorithms
  - [x] Bellman-Ford
  - [x] Dijkstras
  - [x] Breadth-First-Search
  - [x] Depth-First-Search
  - [x] Prims
  - [x] Edmonds-karp
  - [ ] Floyd-warshall
  - [x] Ford-Fulkerson
  - [ ] Bipartite-Matching
  - [ ] Strongly Connected Components

* Data-Structues
  - [x] Directed-Graph
  - [x] UnDirected-Graph
  - [x] Queue
  - [x] Stack
  - [x] General-Tree
  - [ ] Binary-search-tree
  - [ ] Radix-tree
  - [ ] RB-tree

## Contributors

- [mettuaditya](https://github.com/mettuaditya) Aditya Mettu - creator, maintainer

types.name: Graphlb
types.doc:
Graphlb is a framework of Graph data-structures and algorithms which are inspired from the Ruby Graph Library (RGL).

Some data-structures are ported from the Ruby language like *TreeNode* from Ruby Trees
types.summary: Graphlb is a framework of Graph data-structures and algorithms which are inspired from the Ruby Graph Library (RGL).

types.name: Algorithms
types.doc:
Algorithms contain all the general algorithms that can be used on a graph data-structure

like Flow Networks, Graph Traversal, Shortest path between Nodes, Spanning Trees etc.
types.summary: Algorithms contain all the general algorithms that can be used on a graph data-structure

types.name: BellmanFord
types.doc:
Bellman Ford's algorithm is an algorithm for finding
the shortest paths between nodes in a graph,

Given a graph and source vertex Bellman Fords algorithm finds
the shortest distance from the source vertex to all other
vertices in the graph.

It also finds wheather a negative cycle is present in a graph or not
types.summary: Bellman Ford's algorithm is an algorithm for finding the shortest paths between nodes in a graph,

instance_methods.name: path_constructor
instance_methods.summary: constructs a path from source vertex to target vertex

def.name: path_constructor
def.body:
set = [] of String
temp = target.name
while ((!temp.nil?) && (temp != source.name))
  set.insert(0, temp)
  temp = prev[temp]
end
set.insert(0, source.name)
return set

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.summary: Runs the Bellman_Ford Algorithm on the given graph and the source node

def.name: run
def.body:
vertex_set = graph.get_vertices
dist = {} of Node => Float64
prev = {} of String => String | Nil
i = 0
size = vertex_set.size
while i < size
  dist[vertex_set[i]] = Float64::INFINITY
  prev[vertex_set[i].name] = nil
  i = i + 1
end
dist[source] = 0.0
i = 1
while i < (size - 1)
  vertex_set.each do |j|
    j.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
      temp = dist[j] + j.edges[neighbour]
      if temp < dist[neighbour]
        dist[neighbour] = temp
        prev[neighbour.name] = j.name
      end
    end
  end
  i = i + 1
end
vertex_set.each do |j|
  j.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
    temp = dist[j] + j.edges[neighbour]
    if temp < dist[neighbour]
      raise("graph contains negative cycle")
    end
  end
end
return {dist, prev}

types.name: BFS
types.doc:
Breadth first Search is an algorithm for finding
all the vertices that are reachable from  a source,
vertex in a graph.

Given a graph and source vertex Breadth First Search finds
the vertices that are reachable from the source vertex
in a graph
types.summary: Breadth first Search is an algorithm for finding all the vertices that are reachable from a source, vertex in a graph.

instance_methods.name: reachable
instance_methods.summary: Given a graph and a Source vertex the BFS algorithm starts running from the sources vertex to find all the vertices that are reachable from the source vertex and the information about the previous node of all nodes

def.name: reachable
def.body:
vertex_set = [] of Node
vertices = graph.get_vertices
prev = {} of Node => Node | Nil
i = 0
size = vertices.size
while i < size
  prev[vertices[i]] = nil
  vertex_set << vertices[i]
  i = i + 1
end
prev[source] = source
visitedQueue = Queue(String).new
queue = Queue(Node).new
queue.push(source)
while !queue.empty?
  vertex = queue.pop
  if vertex.nil?
    raise("No vertex available in Queue")
  else
    vertex.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
      if (      prev[neighbour].nil? && vertex.edges[neighbour] > 0.0)
        prev[neighbour] = vertex
        queue.push(neighbour)
      end
    end
  end
  visitedQueue.push(vertex.name)
end
return {visitedQueue.values, prev}

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.summary: Given a graph and a Source vertex the BFS algorithm starts running from the sources vertex to find all the vertices that are visited from the source vertex.

def.name: run
def.body:
vertex_set = [] of Node
vertices = graph.get_vertices
dist = {} of Node => Float64
prev = {} of String => String | Nil
i = 0
size = vertices.size
while i < size
  dist[vertices[i]] = Float64::INFINITY
  prev[vertices[i].name] = nil
  vertex_set << vertices[i]
  i = i + 1
end
dist[source] = 0.0
prev[source.name] = source.name
visitedQueue = Queue(String).new
queue = Queue(Node).new
queue.push(source)
while !queue.empty?
  vertex = queue.pop
  if vertex.nil?
    raise("No vertex available in Queue")
  else
    vertex.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
      if prev[neighbour.name].nil?
        dist[neighbour] = dist[vertex] + 1
        prev[neighbour.name] = vertex.name
        queue.push(neighbour)
      end
    end
  end
  visitedQueue.push(vertex.name)
end
return visitedQueue.values

types.name: DFS
types.doc:
Depth first Search is an algorithm for finding
all the vertices that are reachable from  a source,
vertex in a graph.

Given a graph and source vertex Depth First Search finds
the vertices that are reachable from the source vertex
in a graph
types.summary: Depth first Search is an algorithm for finding all the vertices that are reachable from a source, vertex in a graph.

instance_methods.name: reachable
instance_methods.summary: Given a graph and a Source vertex the DFS algorithm starts running from the sources vertex to find all the vertices that are reachable from the source vertex and the information about the previous node of all nodes

def.name: reachable
def.body:
vertex_set = [] of Node
vertices = graph.get_vertices
prev = {} of Node => Node | Nil
i = 0
size = vertices.size
while i < size
  prev[vertices[i]] = nil
  vertex_set << vertices[i]
  i = i + 1
end
prev[source] = source
visitedQueue = Stack(String).new
queue = Stack(Node).new
queue.push(source)
while !queue.empty?
  vertex = queue.pop
  if vertex.nil?
    raise("No vertex available in stack")
  else
    vertex.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
      if (      prev[neighbour].nil? && vertex.edges[neighbour] > 0.0)
        prev[neighbour] = vertex
        queue.push(neighbour)
      end
    end
  end
  visitedQueue.push(vertex.name)
end
return {visitedQueue.values, prev}

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.summary: Given a graph and a Source vertex the DFS algorithm starts running from the sources vertex to find all the vertices that are visited from the source vertex.

def.name: run
def.body:
vertex_set = [] of Node
vertices = graph.get_vertices
dist = {} of Node => Float64
prev = {} of String => String | Nil
i = 0
size = vertices.size
while i < size
  dist[vertices[i]] = Float64::INFINITY
  prev[vertices[i].name] = nil
  vertex_set << vertices[i]
  i = i + 1
end
dist[source] = 0.0
prev[source.name] = source.name
visitedQueue = Stack(String).new
queue = Stack(Node).new
queue.push(source)
while !queue.empty?
  vertex = queue.pop
  if vertex.nil?
    raise("No vertex available in stack")
  else
    vertex.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
      if prev[neighbour.name].nil?
        dist[neighbour] = dist[vertex] + 1
        prev[neighbour.name] = vertex.name
        queue.push(neighbour)
      end
    end
  end
  puts((  vertex.name))
  visitedQueue.push(vertex.name)
end
return visitedQueue.values

types.name: Dijkstras
types.doc:
Dijkstra's algorithm is an algorithm for finding
the shortest paths between nodes in a graph,

Given a graph and source vertex dijkstra function finds
the shortest distance from the source vertex to all other
vertices in the graph
types.summary: Dijkstra's algorithm is an algorithm for finding the shortest paths between nodes in a graph,

instance_methods.name: path_constructor
instance_methods.summary: constructs a path from source vertex to target vertex

def.name: path_constructor
def.body:
set = [] of String
temp = target.name
while ((!temp.nil?) && (temp != source.name))
  set.insert(0, temp)
  temp = prev[temp]
end
set.insert(0, source.name)
return set

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.summary: Runs the Dijkstras Algorithm on the given graph and the source node

def.name: run
def.body:
vertex_set = [] of Node
vertices = graph.get_vertices
dist = {} of Node => Float64
prev = {} of String => String | Nil
i = 0
size = vertices.size
while i < size
  dist[vertices[i]] = Float64::INFINITY
  prev[vertices[i].name] = nil
  vertex_set << vertices[i]
  i = i + 1
end
dist[source] = 0.0
while !vertex_set.empty?
  u = vertex_set.min_by do |n|
    dist.fetch(n, Float64::INFINITY)
  end
  vertex_set.delete(u)
  u.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
    temp = dist[u] + u.edges[neighbour]
    if temp < dist[neighbour]
      dist[neighbour] = temp
      prev[neighbour.name] = u.name
    end
  end
end
return {dist, prev}

types.name: EdmondsKarp
types.doc:
The Edmonds-Karp Algorithm is a specific implementation of the Ford-Fulkerson
algorithm. Like Ford-Fulkerson, Edmonds-Karp is also an algorithm that deals
with the max-flow min-cut problem

Edmonds-Karp differs from Ford-Fulkerson in that it chooses the next augmenting
path using breadth-first search (bfs). So, if there are multiple augmenting
paths to choose from, Edmonds-Karp will be sure to choose the shortest
augmenting path from the source to the sink.
types.summary: The Edmonds-Karp Algorithm is a specific implementation of the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm.

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.summary: Finds the maximum flow in the flow network graph

def.name: run
def.body:
puts(("fot"))
max_flow = 0
rgraph = graph
r_vertices = rgraph.get_vertices
r_vertices.each do |vertex|
  vertex.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
    if (    neighbour.edges.keys.find do |i|
      i == vertex
    end).nil?
      neighbour.add_edge(vertex, 0.0)
    end
  end
end
while (true)
  dfs = DFS.new
  visit_set, prev = dfs.reachable(rgraph, source)
  temp = visit_set.find do |i|
    i == sink.name
  end
  if temp.nil?
    break
  else
    path_len = Float64::INFINITY
    v = sink
    while (    v != source)
      u = prev[v]
      if u.nil?
        raise("invalid input")
      end
      path_len = Math.min(path_len, u.edges[v])
      v = u
    end
    v = sink
    while (    v != source)
      u = prev[v]
      if (      u.nil? || v.nil?)
        raise("invaid input")
      end
      u.edges[v] = u.edges[v] - path_len
      v.edges[u] = v.edges[u] + path_len
      v = u
    end
  end
  max_flow = max_flow + path_len
end
return max_flow

types.name: FordFulkerson
types.doc:
in the graph, to find the maximum possible flow from s to t with following constraints needs to be true:

a) Flow on an edge doesn’t exceed the given capacity of the edge.

b) Incoming flow is equal to outgoing flow for every vertex except s and t.

In ford Fulkerson algorithm An augmenting path is a simple path from source to sink which do not include any
cycles and that pass only through positive weighted edges. A residual network graph
indicates how much more flow is allowed in each edge in the network graph. If there
are no augmenting paths possible from source to sink, then the flow is maximum. The result i.e.
the maximum flow will be the total flow out of source node which is also equal to
total flow in to the sink node.
types.summary: in the graph, to find the maximum possible flow from s to t with following constraints needs to be true:

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.summary: Finds the maximum flow in the flow network graph

def.name: run
def.body:
max_flow = 0
rgraph = graph
r_vertices = rgraph.get_vertices
r_vertices.each do |vertex|
  vertex.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
    if (    neighbour.edges.keys.find do |i|
      i == vertex
    end).nil?
      neighbour.add_edge(vertex, 0.0)
    end
  end
end
while (true)
  bfs = BFS.new
  visit_set, prev = bfs.reachable(rgraph, source)
  temp = visit_set.find do |i|
    i == sink.name
  end
  if temp.nil?
    break
  else
    path_len = Float64::INFINITY
    v = sink
    while (    v != source)
      u = prev[v]
      if u.nil?
        raise("invalid input")
      end
      path_len = Math.min(path_len, u.edges[v])
      v = u
    end
    v = sink
    while (    v != source)
      u = prev[v]
      if (      u.nil? || v.nil?)
        raise("invaid input")
      end
      u.edges[v] = u.edges[v] - path_len
      v.edges[u] = v.edges[u] + path_len
      v = u
    end
  end
  max_flow = max_flow + path_len
end
return max_flow

types.name: Prims
types.doc:
Prim's algorithm is an algorithm for finding
the Minimum spanning tree in a graph, i.e the tree
with the lowest weight

Given a graph and source vertex dijkstra function finds
the shortest distance from the source vertex to all other
vertices in the graph
types.summary: Prim's algorithm is an algorithm for finding the Minimum spanning tree in a graph, i.e the tree with the lowest weight

instance_methods.name: path_constructor
instance_methods.summary: constructs a path from source vertex to target vertex

def.name: path_constructor
def.body:
set = [] of String
temp = target.name
while ((!temp.nil?) && (temp != source.name))
  set.insert(0, temp)
  temp = prev[temp]
end
set.insert(0, source.name)
return set

instance_methods.name: run
instance_methods.doc:
returns a hashes, which contains the information about the
previous vertex of all the vertives present inside the graph
instance_methods.summary: returns a hashes, which contains the information about the previous vertex of all the vertives present inside the graph

def.name: run
def.body:
vertex_set = graph.get_vertices
dist = {} of Node => Float64
prev = {} of String => String | Nil
visit_set = {} of Node => Bool
i = 0
size = vertex_set.size
while i < size
  dist[vertex_set[i]] = Float64::INFINITY
  prev[vertex_set[i].name] = nil
  visit_set[vertex_set[i]] = false
  i = i + 1
end
dist[source] = 0.0
while !vertex_set.empty?
  u = vertex_set.min_by do |n|
    dist.fetch(n, Float64::INFINITY)
  end
  vertex_set.delete(u)
  visit_set[u] = true
  u.edges.keys.each do |neighbour|
    if u.edges[neighbour] < dist[neighbour] && (visit_set[neighbour] == false)
      dist[neighbour] = u.edges[neighbour]
      prev[neighbour.name] = u.name
    end
  end
end
return prev

types.name: DataStructures
types.doc:
In the module the we have defined the data-structures starting from the simple Node data-structure to a complex tree data-structure
which will be used in many general graph algorithms to obtain efficient solutions.

These are Just some of the basic data-structures and more data-structures will be added as we move between different algorithms.
types.summary: In the module the we have defined the data-structures starting from the simple Node data-structure to a complex tree data-structure which will be used in many general graph algorithms to obtain efficient solutions.

types.name: BinaryTreeNode
types.doc:
Provides a Binary tree implementation. This node allows only two child nodes
(left and right child). It also provides direct access to the left or right
child, including assignment to the same.

This inherits from the {TreeNode} class.

instance_methods.name: is_left_child?
instance_methods.summary: true if the receiver node is the left child of its parent.

def.name: is_left_child?
def.body:
if is_root?
  return false
end
self == parent.left_child

instance_methods.name: is_right_child?
instance_methods.summary: true if the receiver node is the right child of its parent.

def.name: is_right_child?
def.body:
if is_root?
  return false
end
self == parent.right_child

instance_methods.name: left_child
instance_methods.doc:
Left child of the receiver node. Note that left Child == first Child.

@return [BinaryTreeNode] The left most (or first) child.
instance_methods.summary: Left child of the receiver node.

instance_methods.name: left_child=
instance_methods.summary: Sets the left child of the receiver node.

instance_methods.name: right_child
instance_methods.doc:
Right child of the receiver node. Note that right child == last child
unless there is only one child.

Returns *nil* if the right child does not exist.

@return [BinaryTreeNode] The right child, or *nil* if the right side
child does not exist.
instance_methods.summary: Right child of the receiver node.

instance_methods.name: right_child=
instance_methods.summary: Sets the right child of the receiver node.

instance_methods.name: swap_children
instance_methods.doc: Swaps the left and right child nodes of the receiver node with each other.
instance_methods.summary: Swaps the left and right child nodes of the receiver node with each other.

types.name: DirectedGraph
types.doc:
A directed graph (or digraph) is a graph that is made up of a set of vertices connected by edges,
where the edges have a direction and weight associated with them.

The class provides various methods which can be used to define/modify a simple directed graph with edge-weight
Associated to each edge. Here we are using the adjacency list approach to define a directed graph which
can be modified later as per convience
types.summary: A directed graph (or digraph) is a graph that is made up of a set of vertices connected by edges, where the edges have a direction and weight associated with them.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: creats a graph whith no vertices and edges(empty-graph)
constructors.summary: creats a graph whith no vertices and edges(empty-graph)

instance_methods.name: add_edge
instance_methods.summary: Creates an edge between the nodes provided as the parametes.

def.name: add_edge
def.body:
from = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == from_node
end
to = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == to_node
end
if (from.nil? || to.nil?)
  raise("Node not found")
else
  from.add_edge(to_node, weight)
end

instance_methods.name: add_vertex
instance_methods.summary: Creates a new vertex with in the graph.

instance_methods.name: get_vertices
instance_methods.doc:
returns informaton about all the vertices inside the graph

@return : list of all vertices/nodes in the graph
instance_methods.summary: returns informaton about all the vertices inside the graph

instance_methods.name: remove_edge
instance_methods.summary: Removes the edge form the from_node to the to_node present in the graph

def.name: remove_edge
def.body:
node = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == from_node
end
if node.nil?
  raise("Node not found")
else
  if node.edges.has_key?(to_node)
    node.remove_edge(to_node)
  else
    raise("edge not found")
  end
end

instance_methods.name: vertices
instance_methods.doc: All the vertices of the graph are stored in this variables
instance_methods.summary: All the vertices of the graph are stored in this variables

types.name: Node
types.doc:
The node Class basically represnts the vertices in a graph
it contains two properties
  1. name of the vertex
  2. edge shared with other vertex

edges property in Node reprensents the adjacency graph which
is implemented using a hash with vertex name as it key
and edge weight as its value

types.name: Queue
types.doc:
In crystal, elements in an array are added in dynamics fashion means
the size of the array is not fixed which makes them quite similar
to linked list.

Here we have implemented the Queue Data Structure using an Array. A Queue follows First-in-First-out.
types.summary: In crystal, elements in an array are added in dynamics fashion means the size of the array is not fixed which makes them quite similar to linked list.

Here we have implemanted the stack data-structure using an array.A stack follows Last-in-First-out.

types.name: TreeNode
types.doc:
TreeNode Class Description

This class models the nodes for an *N-ary* tree data structure. The
nodes are *named*, and have a place-holder for the node data (i.e.,
_content_ of the node). The node names are required to be *unique*
amongst the sibling/peer nodes. Note that the name is implicitly
used as an _ID_ within the data structure).

The node's _content_ is *not* required to be unique across
different nodes in the tree, and can be +nil+ as well.

The class provides various methods to navigate the tree, traverse
the structure, modify contents of the node, change position of the
node in the tree, and to make structural changes to the tree.

A node can have any number of *child* nodes attached to it and
hence can be used to create N-ary trees.  Access to the child
nodes can be made in order (with the conventional left to right
access), or randomly.

The node also provides direct access to its *parent* node as well
as other superior parents in the path to root of the tree.  In
addition, a node can also access its *sibling* nodes, if present.

constructors.name: new
constructors.summary: Creates a new node with a name and optional content.

instance_methods.summary: Convenience synonym for {TreeNode#add} method.

instance_methods.doc:
Returns the requested node from the set of immediate children.

- If the +name+ argument is an _Integer_, then the in-sequence
  array of children is accessed using the argument as the
  *index* (zero-based).  However, if the second _optional_
  +num_as_name+ argument is +true+, then the +name+ is used
  literally as a name, and *NOT* as an *index*

- If the +name+ argument is *NOT* an _Integer_, then it is taken to
  be the *name* of the child node to be returned.

If a non-+Integer+ +name+ is passed, and the +num_as_name+
parameter is also +true+, then a warning is thrown (as this is a
redundant use of the +num_as_name+ flag.)

@param [String|Number] name_or_index Name of the child, or its
  positional index in the array of child nodes.

@param [Boolean] num_as_name Whether to treat the +Integer+
  +name+ argument as an actual name, and *NOT* as an _index_ to
  the children array.

@return [TreeNode] the requested child node.  If the index
  in not in range, or the name is not present, then a +nil+
  is returned.

 @raise [Error] Raised if the +name_or_index+ argument is +nil+.
instance_methods.summary: Returns the requested node from the set of immediate children.

instance_methods.name: add
instance_methods.summary: Adds the specified child node to this node.

def.name: add
def.body:
if child
else
  raise("Attempting to add a nil node")
end
if self == child
  raise("Attempting add node to itself")
end
if child == root
  raise("Attempting add root as a child")
end
if @children_hash.includes?(child.name)
  raise("child #{child.name} already added!")
end
if insertion_range.includes?(at_index)
  @children.insert(at_index, child)
else
  raise("attempting to insert a child at a non-existing location")
end
@children_hash[child.name] = child
child.parent = self
child

instance_methods.name: children
instance_methods.doc:
Method oveloading of the children method

An array of all the immediate children of this node. The child
nodes are ordered "left-to-right" in the returned array.

@return [Array<TreeNode>] An array of the child nodes.
instance_methods.summary: Method oveloading of the children method

instance_methods.name: children
instance_methods.summary: An array of all the immediate children of this node.

instance_methods.name: content
instance_methods.doc:
Content of this node.  Can be +nil+.  Note that there is no
uniqueness constraint related to this attribute.
instance_methods.summary: Content of this node.

instance_methods.name: content=
instance_methods.doc:
Content of this node.  Can be +nil+.  Note that there is no
uniqueness constraint related to this attribute.
instance_methods.summary: Content of this node.

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.summary: Traverses each node (including this node) of the (sub)tree rooted at this node by yielding the nodes to the specified block.

def.name: each
def.body:
node_stack = [self]
while !node_stack.empty?
  current = node_stack.shift
  if current
    yield current
    node_stack = current.children.concat(node_stack)
  end
end
self

instance_methods.name: each
instance_methods.summary: Traverses each node (including this node) of the (sub)tree rooted at this node

instance_methods.name: each_leaf
instance_methods.doc:
Method oveloading of the each_leaf method without block parameter

@return [Array<TreeNode>] An array of the leaf nodes
instance_methods.summary: Method oveloading of the each_leaf method without block parameter

instance_methods.name: each_leaf
instance_methods.summary: Yields every leaf node of the (sub)tree rooted at this node to the specified block.

def.name: each_leaf
def.body:
self.each do |node|
  if node.is_leaf?
    yield node
  end
end
self

instance_methods.name: first_sibling
instance_methods.doc:
First sibling of this node. If this is the root node, then returns
itself.

'First' sibling is defined as follows:

First sibling:: The left-most child of this node's parent, which may be
this node itself

@return [TreeNode] The first sibling node.
instance_methods.summary: First sibling of this node.

instance_methods.name: has_children?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns *true* if the this node has any child node.

@return [Boolean] +true+ if child nodes exist.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if the this node has any child node.

instance_methods.name: has_content?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns *true* if this node has content.

@return [Boolean] +true+ if the node has content.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this node has content.

instance_methods.name: in_degree
instance_methods.doc:
The incoming edge-count of this node.

In-degree is defined as:
In-degree:: Number of edges arriving at the node (0 for root, 1 for
all other nodes)

- In-degree = 0 for a root or orphaned node
- In-degree = 1 for a node which has a parent

@return [Integer] The in-degree of this node.
instance_methods.summary: The incoming edge-count of this node.

instance_methods.name: insertion_range
instance_methods.doc: Return a range of valid insertion positions.  Used in the #add method.
instance_methods.summary: Return a range of valid insertion positions.

instance_methods.name: is_first_sibling?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns *true* if this node is the first sibling at its level.

@return [Boolean] *true* if this is the first sibling.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this node is the first sibling at its level.

instance_methods.name: is_last_sibling?
instance_methods.doc:
Returns *true* if this node is the last sibling at its level.

@return [Boolean] +true+ if this is the last sibling.
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this node is the last sibling at its level.

instance_methods.name: is_leaf?
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this node is a leaf - i.e., one without any children.

instance_methods.name: is_only_child?
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this node is the only child of its parent.

instance_methods.name: is_root?
instance_methods.summary: Returns true if this is a root node.

instance_methods.name: lam
instance_methods.doc:
Helper function for print_tree method to print the
tree with given root
instance_methods.summary: Helper function for print_tree method to print the tree with given root

instance_methods.name: last_sibling
instance_methods.doc:
Last sibling of this node.  If this is the root node, then returns
itself.

'Last' sibling is defined as follows:

Last sibling:: The right-most child of this node's parent, which may be
this node itself

@return [TreeNode] The last sibling node.
instance_methods.summary: Last sibling of this node.

instance_methods.name: name
instance_methods.doc:
Name of this node.  Expected to be unique within the tree.

Note that the name attribute really functions as an *ID* within
the tree structure, and hence the uniqueness constraint is
required.
instance_methods.summary: Name of this node.

instance_methods.name: next_sibling
instance_methods.doc:
Next sibling for this node.
The _next_ node is defined as the node to right of this node.

Will return +nil+ if no subsequent node is present, or if this is a root
node.

@return [treeNode] the next sibling node, if present.
instance_methods.summary: Next sibling for this node.

def.name: next_sibling
def.body:
if is_root?
  return nil
end
idx = parent.not_nil!.children.index(self)
if idx
  parent.not_nil!.children[idx + 1]
end

instance_methods.name: node_depth
instance_methods.doc:
Depth of this node in its tree.  Depth of a node is defined as:

Depth:: Length of the node's path to its root. Depth of a root node is
zero.

@return [Integer] Depth of this node.
instance_methods.summary: Depth of this node in its tree.

instance_methods.name: node_height
instance_methods.doc:
Height of the (sub)tree from this node.  Height of a node is defined as:

Height:: Length of the longest downward path to a leaf from the node.

- Height from a root node is height of the entire tree.
- The height of a leaf node is zero.

@return [Integer] Height of the node.
instance_methods.summary: Height of the (sub)tree from this node.

def.name: node_height
def.body:
if is_leaf?
  return 0
end
1 + @children.collect do |child|
  child.node_height
end.max

instance_methods.name: out_degree
instance_methods.doc:
The outgoing edge-count of this node.

Out-degree is defined as:
Out-degree:: Number of edges leaving the node (zero for leafs)

@return [Integer] The out-degree of this node.
instance_methods.summary: The outgoing edge-count of this node.

instance_methods.name: parent
instance_methods.doc: Parent of this node.  Will be +nil+ for a root node.
instance_methods.summary: Parent of this node.

instance_methods.name: parent=
instance_methods.summary: Method to set the parent node for this node.

instance_methods.name: parentage
instance_methods.summary: An array of ancestors of this node in reversed order (the first element is the immediate parent of this node).

def.name: parentage
def.body:
if is_root?
  return nil
end
parentage_array = [] of TreeNode
prev_parent = self.parent
while prev_parent
  parentage_array << prev_parent
  prev_parent = prev_parent.parent
end
parentage_array

instance_methods.name: previous_sibling
instance_methods.doc:
Previous sibling of this node.
_Previous_ node is defined to be the node to left of this node.

Will return +nil+ if no predecessor node is present, or if this is a root
node.

@return [treeNode] the previous sibling node, if present.
instance_methods.summary: Previous sibling of this node.

def.name: previous_sibling
def.body:
if is_root?
  return nil
end
idx = parent.not_nil!.children.index(self)
if idx && idx > 0
  parent.not_nil!.children[idx - 1]
end

instance_methods.name: print_tree
instance_methods.summary: Pretty prints the (sub)tree rooted at this node.

def.name: print_tree
def.body:
prefix = ""
if is_root?
  prefix = prefix + "*"
else
  if parent.not_nil!.is_last_sibling?
  else
    prefix = prefix + '|'
  end
  prefix = prefix + ((" " * (level - 1)) * 4)
  prefix = prefix + (is_last_sibling? ? '+' : '|')
  prefix = prefix + "---"
  prefix = prefix + (has_children? ? '+' : '>')
end
lam(self, prefix)
if max_depth.nil? || level < max_depth
else
  return
end
children do |child|
  if child
    child.print_tree(level + 1, max_depth)
  end
end

instance_methods.name: remove!
instance_methods.doc:
Removes the specified child node from this node.

This method can also be used for *pruning* a sub-tree, in cases where the removed child node is
the root of the sub-tree to be pruned.

The removed child node is orphaned but accessible if an alternate reference exists.  If accessible via
an alternate reference, the removed child will report itself as a root node for its sub-tree.

@param [TreeNode] child The child node to remove.

@return [TreeNode] The removed child node, or +nil+ if a +nil+ was passed in as argument.
instance_methods.summary: Removes the specified child node from this node.

def.name: remove!
def.body:
if child
else
  return nil
end
@children_hash.delete(child.name)
@children.delete(child)
child.set_as_root!
child

instance_methods.name: remove_from_parent!
instance_methods.doc:
Removes this node from its parent. This node becomes the new root for its
subtree.

If this is the root node, then does nothing.

@return [TreeNode] +self+ (the removed node) if the operation is
                               successful, +nil+ otherwise.
instance_methods.summary: Removes this node from its parent.

instance_methods.name: rename
instance_methods.summary: Renames the node and updates the parent's reference to it

def.name: rename
def.body:
old_name = @name
if is_root?
  self.name = (  new_name)
else
  @parent.rename_child(old_name, new_name)
end
old_name

instance_methods.name: replace!
instance_methods.summary: Replaces the specified child node with another child node on this node.

def.name: replace!
def.body:
child_index = @children.index(old_child)
old_child = remove!(old_child)
add(new_child, child_index)
old_child

instance_methods.name: replace_with
instance_methods.summary: Replaces the node with another node

instance_methods.name: root
instance_methods.summary: Root node for the (sub)tree to which this node belongs.

def.name: root
def.body:
root = self
while !root.not_nil!.is_root?
  root = root.not_nil!.parent
end
root

instance_methods.name: set_as_root!
instance_methods.doc:
Method to set this node as a root node.

@return +nil+.
instance_methods.summary: Method to set this node as a root node.

instance_methods.name: siblings
instance_methods.summary: An array of siblings for this node.

def.name: siblings
def.body:
if is_root?
  return [] of TreeNode
end
siblings = [] of TreeNode
if parent.nil?
  raise("There are no siblings of the node/root node")
else
  parent.not_nil!.children do |my_sibling|
    if my_sibling != self
      siblings << my_sibling
    end
  end
  siblings
end

types.name: UnDirectedGraph
types.doc:
An undirected graph is a graph that is made up of a set of vertices connected by edges,
where the edges have a not direction and weight are associated with the edges.

The class provides various methods which can be used to define/modify a simple undirected graph with edge-weight
Associated to each edge. Here we are using the adjacency list approach to define a undirected graph which
can be modified later as per convience
types.summary: An undirected graph is a graph that is made up of a set of vertices connected by edges, where the edges have a not direction and weight are associated with the edges.

constructors.name: new
constructors.doc: creats a graph whith no vertices and edges(empty-graph)
constructors.summary: creats a graph whith no vertices and edges(empty-graph)

instance_methods.name: add_edge
instance_methods.summary: Creates an edge between the nodes provided as the parametes.

def.name: add_edge
def.body:
from = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == from_node
end
to = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == to_node
end
if (from.nil? || to.nil?)
  raise("Node not found")
else
  from.add_edge(to_node, weight)
  to.add_edge(from_node, weight)
end

instance_methods.name: add_vertex
instance_methods.summary: Creates a new vertex with in the graph.

instance_methods.name: get_vertices
instance_methods.doc:
returns informaton about all the vertices inside the graph

@return : list of all vertices/nodes in the graph
instance_methods.summary: returns informaton about all the vertices inside the graph

instance_methods.name: remove_edge
instance_methods.summary: Removes the edge form the from_node to the to_node present in the graph

def.name: remove_edge
def.body:
from = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == from_node
end
to = @vertices.find do |i|
  i == to_node
end
if (node.nil? || to.nil?)
  raise("Node not found")
else
  if (  (from.edges.has_key?(to)) && (to.edges.has_key?(from)))
    from.remove_edge(to_node)
    to.remove_edge(from_node)
  else
    raise("edge not found")
  end
end

instance_methods.name: vertices
instance_methods.doc: All the vertices of the graph are stored in this variables
instance_methods.summary: All the vertices of the graph are stored in this variables
